citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A female llama (Peppen) ) appears to be underweight. She was observed to have a sharp upward slant or exaggerated
“tuck” in her abdominal area. When palpated, individual ribs were easily felt and there was only a thin layer of muscle or
fat over her hips and at the back of her hips. Peppen is in a pen with another llama who was in good condition.
Poor body condition can be the result of parasites, inadequate nutrition, or an underlying medical condition. Peppen must
be evaluated by a veterinarian to know with certainty the problem and the correct treatment. Documentation of the
evaluation, recommended treatment and delivered treatments must be available to APHIS officials. Each dealer or
exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to
prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.
To be corrected by 15 March 2024

The facility does not have a developed and documented contingency plan that provides direction to provide for the
humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster.
An outlined plan is necessary to prepare for unexpected disasters or events, as well as a detailed strategy to address
instructions for, but not limited to: animal evacuation, sheltering-in-place, and backup provisions for husbandry and
food/watering supplies, sanitation, and ventilation. The facility shall develop and document an appropriate contingency
plan available for review upon USDA inspection, ensuring the written contingency plan includes an outline of the specific
tasks required to be carried out in response to the identified emergencies/disasters.
Correction date: 15 March 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
